content: How can I help you today?
I'm not sure, honestly. I'm here because my wife thought it was important, but I don't really know if this will help. We've been dealing with a lot at home, and it's hard to even know where to start.

That sounds like a lot to carry—it’s understandable to feel unsure about where to begin. Maybe we can start by talking about what’s been going on at home or what’s on your mind right now. Whatever feels comfortable for you.

I guess the biggest challenge has been my son. He's been acting out a lot, and my wife and I just don't know how to handle it anymore. It's causing so much stress between us, and I feel like we're falling apart trying to figure it out.

It sounds like your son's behavior has been a big source of stress for both you and your wife, and it’s been taking a toll on your relationship as you try to navigate it all. That must feel overwhelming at times. How have you been managing with everything going on?

Honestly, I don’t think I am managing it well. I can’t focus at work, I don’t enjoy anything I used to, and I feel like I’m just constantly on edge. It’s hard to even know what to do for him, and it’s making everything else in my life feel so much harder.

It sounds like you’re carrying a lot right now, and it’s having an impact on so many areas of your life—your work, your interests, and your well-being. It’s tough when you feel stretched like that, especially while trying to be there for your son. What do you think has been the hardest part of all this for you personally?

I think the hardest part is feeling like I’m failing everyone—my son, my wife, and even my daughter. No matter what I try, it doesn’t feel like enough, and I just don’t know how to fix any of it. It’s like everything is slipping out of my hands.

It sounds incredibly heavy to feel like you’re trying so hard but still feeling as if it’s not enough. That sense of wanting to fix things for the people you care about must weigh on you deeply. What do you feel like you need right now to lighten that burden, even just a little?

I'm not sure what I need, to be honest. Everything feels so tangled, and I wouldn't even know where to start fixing it. I guess I just feel stuck, and maybe that's why I'm even here—because I don't know what else to do.

Feeling stuck can be so hard—it’s like you’re carrying this heavy load and not sure which way to turn. The fact that you’re here and open to talking shows you’re trying to figure things out, even in this tough time. That’s no small thing. What are some things you’ve tried already, even if they didn’t feel like enough?

We’ve tried different things with my son—talking to him, setting boundaries, even being more lenient at times—but nothing seems to work. My wife and I have talked about it endlessly, but it usually turns into an argument or just leaves us feeling more hopeless. It feels like every option we try ends up making things worse somehow.

It sounds like you’ve both been putting in a lot of effort to support your son, trying different approaches, even when the outcomes have been frustrating. It’s clear how much you care about your family, even when things feel so difficult. What do you think has made those conversations or efforts feel as overwhelming as they’ve been?

I think it’s the constant feeling of not having answers and the tension it creates between my wife and me. Every time we hit a dead end with my son, it just feels like we’re failing again, and the stress of that builds up between us. It’s like we’re stuck in this cycle, and I don’t know how to break out of it.

It sounds like the cycle of not having clear answers and the weight of feeling like you're not making progress is feeding into a lot of the tension and frustration for both of you. That must feel exhausting, especially since you’re trying to do your best for your son. What do you think breaking that cycle might look like for you and your family?

It’s hard to even imagine what that looks like right now. I guess finding some way to feel like we’re moving forward, even just a little, would help. But I honestly don’t know how to get there—or if it’s even possible.

It’s difficult to imagine change when things feel so overwhelming, but the hope for even small progress is an important step. It shows that deep down, you care about finding a way forward for your family. What would taking even the smallest step forward mean to you, if that were possible?

I think just feeling like I’m not failing—like there’s hope that things can get better—would mean a lot. Even if it’s something small, just some sign that all this effort isn’t pointless would help me keep going.

Finding that small sign of progress sounds like it could really help you feel a sense of hope and reinforce that your efforts truly do matter. Holding onto that hope, even when it feels faint, can be powerful. If you paused and thought about one small thing that you or your family is doing well, what might come to mind?
I guess the one thing would be that we’re still trying. Even though things feel hopeless sometimes, my wife and I haven’t given up on our son or each other yet. Maybe that counts for something.

It absolutely counts for something—continuing to try, even through all the challenges and doubts, shows just how committed you are to your son and your family. That dedication is such a strength, even in moments when progress feels hard to see. How does it feel to recognize that you and your wife are still in this together?
